http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: In Grades K-7, students receive a strong foundation in social studies and United States history prior to its founding through the 18th century. Grade 8 Social Studies has an emphasis on United States history from 1801 expansion and reform to 1900 industrial America. The desired outcome of this course is for students to develop an understanding of the cause-and-effect relationship between events, recognize patterns of interactions, and understand the impact of events in the United States within an interconnected world. The history of the United States during the nineteenth century includes the integration of social, political, economic, and geographic components. The history strand in Grade 8 is organized chronologically using the eras and time periods from The National Center for History in the Schools. Civics/government, economics, and geography should be embedded into instructional units that correlate with the historic eras under study.
Era 4: Expansion and Reform 1801-1861
Students will analyze the period of expansion and reform in the United States.
Analyze multiple factors that affected territorial expansion and influenced the perspectives of people

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., Manifest Destiny, mining, War of 1812, Louisiana Purchase

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Analyze the development of regional tensions prior to the Civil War using a variety of primary and secondary sources

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., Industrial Revolution, expansion of slavery, immigration, westward movement

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Examine economic, political, and geographic causes and effects of territorial expansion
Analyze purposes, implementation, and effects of public policies

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., currency and banking, Indian Removal, disenfranchisement, economic growth, Manifest Destiny

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Evaluate actual and proposed laws as a means of addressing the issue of slavery prior to the Civil War

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., Fugitive Slave Act, Kansas-Nebraska Act, Missouri Compromise, Compromise of 1850

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Evaluate the historical significance of individuals, groups, and events
Era 5: Civil War and Reconstruction 1850-1877
Students will analyze the American Civil War and Reconstruction and their effects on the social, economic, and political development of America.
Develop historical arguments and explanations of causes of the Civil War using a variety of sources from multiple perspectives

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., federal government vs. state's rights, sectionalism, cultural differences between the North and South, abolitionism

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Explain ways economic decisions affected individuals, businesses, and society during the course of the Civil War and over time
Analyze social and economic effects of the Civil War on America
Analyze the historical significance of selected Civil War battles, events, and people
Evaluate the legacy of the Civil War on the nation
Evaluate successes and failures of Reconstruction

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., Reconstruction Plans, Freedman's Bureau, Civil War Amendments, African- American economic positions, sharecropping, crop liens, public education, African- American role in government

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Era 6: Development of the Industrial United States 1870-1900
Students will analyze the development of the industrial United States and the economic and cultural transformation that led to modern America.
Analyze economic, geographic, and technological growth associated with the Second Industrial Revolution and its impact on American society
Examine the effects of immigration after 1870

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., social patterns, national unity, cultural diversity, conflicts

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Analyze the historical significance of individuals, groups, and events
Examine government policies and laws that addressed the escalating labor conflicts and the rise of labor unions using primary and secondary sources
Analyze responses to social, economic, and political issues prior to 1900

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., successes and failures of Populism, economic depressions, civil service reform, Tammany Hall, business regulations

http://purl.org/dc/terms/description.value: Evaluate federal Indian policy, westward expansion, and the resulting struggles from a variety of perspectives using multiple sources
Explain the origins and development of American expansionism

http://purl.org/ASN/schema/core/comment.value: e.g., acquisition of new territories, Spanish-American War, expansionist foreign policy, Filipino insurrection
